briefing.opening: Good morning. I will now begin the climate briefing for January 9, 2026.

sections.title: ğŸ”´ U.S. Withdrawal from Climate Agreements and International Repercussions
sections.content: Former U.S. President Trump has once again withdrawn from the UN Climate Convention and also pulled funding from the Green Climate Fund (GCF), headquartered in Songdo, Incheon, casting a shadow over international climate cooperation [2, 7]. This U.S. decision has drawn heightened criticism, especially as it comes after the IPCC clearly stated that human activities are the primary cause of climate change [23]. Questions are being raised about what the U.S. withdrawal from global climate treaties will mean for climate action [33, 34], potentially causing significant setbacks to international collective response efforts.

sections.title: âš ï¸ Real-world Impacts of Climate Change: Reshaping Winter and Societal Costs
sections.content: Globally, climate change is reshaping the characteristics of winter, directly impacting our daily lives [22]. Domestically, the effects are directly felt, with winter festivals being successively canceled or postponed due to warmer winters [4]. Just as the ice on India's Chadar River is being affected by climate change, threatening the livelihoods of ice transporters [26], climate change is also causing severe problems for the livelihoods and cultures of specific local communities.

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Multifaceted Efforts for Domestic Carbon Neutrality
sections.content: Domestically, multifaceted efforts are underway to achieve a carbon-neutral society. The Rural Development Administration (RDA) has recognized the impact of climate change on agriculture and launched an 'online educational course for low-carbon agricultural products' [1], and the Fruit Growers Association has also begun free winter orchard management training to address climate change [5]. Pyeongtaek City is promoting 37 technology dissemination projects for climate change response [3, 6], and Daegu City presented the goal of 'realizing a pleasant carbon-neutral city' in its 2026 environmental and water resources work report [11]. Furthermore, Changwon City in Gyeongnam is encouraging eco-friendly transportation by increasing carbon neutrality points for users of its public bicycle 'Nubija' [10], and the Cheongju City Policy Institute is recruiting carbon neutrality research talent [13], demonstrating active participation from various local governments and institutions in overcoming the climate crisis [8, 12]. Korea Southern Power (KOSPO) also showed efforts to find solutions on-site through inspections of its renewable energy equity-invested companies [16].

sections.title: ğŸŒ International Climate Action and Perception
sections.content: The international community is demonstrating diverse approaches and perceptions regarding climate change. While the European Union (EU) has been observed to be taking a pause in its 'carbon neutrality' policy implementation [9, 14], Delaware is moving towards net-zero emissions targets through its climate action plan [27]. Bill Gates has emphasized the need for funding in climate change and child health sectors [18], and discussions are actively underway on how to build more resilient communities to climate change [21]. Meanwhile, as the overall status of climate change is being presented as of 2026 [19], a perception has emerged that most people believe climate change primarily affects others [25], suggesting a lack of universal awareness of the climate crisis. Past global warming cases are providing insights into future precipitation patterns, emphasizing the importance of climate change research [28].

sections.title: âš ï¸ Challenges and Controversies in Climate Policy
sections.content: Several challenges and controversies are being raised in the implementation of climate policies. Lee Sang-il, Mayor of Yongin Special City, stated that RE100 is not mandatory, revealing the opaque status of Yongin City's renewable energy plans [17]. Furthermore, some argue that climate policies are driven by 'meaningless numbers,' raising questions about their effectiveness [29]. In addition, scientific and political debates continue regarding the direction of climate change response, including hearings held on movements to ban research into technological climate interventions, such as the use of reflective particles for solar reflection, also known as 'geoengineering' [32].

briefing.closing: Through today's briefing, we have examined the urgent threat of climate change, along with various domestic and international efforts to overcome it, and the policy challenges that still persist. This concludes today's climate briefing.

articles.title: Some want to ban geoengineering research. This would be a catastrophic mistake for our planet | Craig Segall and Baroness Bryony Worthington
articles.description: Weâ€™ve already geoengineered the planet through the careless release of greenhouse gases. Now we need a plan to manage the risks weâ€™ve set in motionA few months ago, Marjorie Taylor Greene, then a Georgia representative, held a hearing on her bill to ban research on â€œgeoengineeringâ€, which refers to technological climate interventions, such as using reflective particles to reflect away sunlight. The hearing represented something of a first â€“ a Republican raising alarm bells about human activity a

summary.phenomenon: A few months ago, Marjorie Taylor Greene, then a Georgia representative, held a hearing on her bill to ban research on 'geoengineering,' which refers to technological climate interventions such as using reflective particles to reflect away sunlight. This hearing was one of the first instances where a Republican raised alarms about human activity.
summary.cause: The underlying recognition is that humanity has already geoengineered the planet through the careless release of greenhouse gases, and a plan is needed to manage the risks that have arisen from this.
